description: The number of homeless individuals in Pasadena held relatively steady in 2020, down just 3% from 2019, but the decline may be statistically insignificant, officials say. Still, when statewide and county homeless counts were seeing double-digit increases in previous years, Pasadena's tally was a "noteworthy success," a city staff report reads, and it's...
text:
The number of homeless individuals in Pasadena held relatively steady in 2020,
down just 3% from 2019, but the decline may be statistically insignificant,
officials say.

Still, when statewide and county homeless counts were seeing double-digit
increases in previous years, Pasadena's tally was a "noteworthy success," a
city staff report reads, and it's something Union Station Homeless Services
Chief Executive Anne Miskey can get behind, even if she's not entirely
satisfied.

"We are pleased the results have not gone up," Miskey said in an interview on
Monday. "Compared to the numbers we're seeing in the rest of the county, I
think it is a testament to the work that's happening in Pasadena."

Figures from the Los Angeles Countywide count, conducted in January by the Los
Angeles Homeless Services Authority, are not yet publicly available. The
numbers for Pasadena, which conducts its own point-in-time count, typically
are announced first.

Miskey celebrated the coordination and support seen between organizations like
hers, the city's housing, police and fire departments, and the local faith
community.

"There's a level of cooperation that's happening here, compared to other
communities," Miskey said. "It's those connections as a community that, I
think, have set us apart, and it's something we have to cultivate going
forward."

Still, while the results weren't bad, they weren't that great either, she
said.

"It's not the numbers we want to see," Miskey said. "We want to see them going
down dramatically.  We're on the right track in the community, but this is a
time for us to do more and do even better."

The homeless count isn't meant to be a holistic accounting of every single
homeless person in the city. It's supposed to be a snapshot of one night in
Pasadena - in this case, Jan. 22, 2020.

Compared to 2019, when city volunteers counted 542 people experiencing
homelessness, this year they counted 527.

"While the exact number of people experiencing homelessness fluctuates on a
daily basis, generally Pasadena's numbers are holding stable following a
steady downward trend since 2011," the staff report reads.

Officials say there's 5% more people living in the city's homeless shelters
compared to 2019. Compared to the overall count, there's less wiggle room on
these figures, Miskey said, because it's significantly easier for officials to
get accurate counts of the population living in shelters.

"Once you're in a shelter, staff are working with you directly to get you into
housing," she said, something that Pasadena has done well compared to its
neighbors.

Miskey said the city has found homes for "a tremendous amount of people," but
more become homeless in Pasadena on a daily basis.

The staff report says that 54% of the people surveyed had been living in
Pasadena before they became homeless. On average, they lived in homes or
apartments in the city for 21 years before they ended up on the streets.

The two hardest hit populations are black or elderly, the report says, and it
dovetails with national trends, Miskey said.

Compared to 2019, Pasadena saw a 27% increase in homelessness among people
ages 62 years or older, the report says. That's despite the fact the
demographic only comprises 14% of the city's population.

The trend holds when one looks at older adults, 55 years old and up, which
make up 30% of the city's overall population and 40% of the homeless
population.

Miskey said this is a trend they've seen around the country, and the seniors
who end up homeless are often experiencing it for the first time. They land on
the streets when they can't afford the skyrocketing rent increases after their
incomes are cut dramatically when, for instance, their spouse dies.

It's an issue Pasadena has focused on for the past few years and is poised to
do more with soon, as the city has approved key components of a housing
project at Heritage Square South, specifically designed for low-income and
homeless seniors.

In the African American population, Pasadena's figures held relatively steady
compared to 2019 - they're still hugely overrepresented with 31% of the
homeless population but only 10% of the city's general population.

"That's true across the country and is a direct result of years of policies
that have disproportionately affected black and other communities of color,"
Miskey said. "Ultimately, blacks were kept out of the housing ownership
market, which forced them into rental housing, then we see the dramatic
increases in rent in the country and people who have very little equity and
forced into low paying jobs.

"All these things come together to make the perfect storm."

Other notable statistics:

* Veterans comprise 7% of the homeless population counted in 2020, which is "relatively stable compared to previous years," the report says.

* The chronically homeless make up slightly more than half of the city's homeless population.

* For the second year in a row, there were no unsheltered homeless families in Pasadena, but 24 families with children were living in the city's shelters. It's a similar proportion that officials saw in 2019.

For Miskey, the key to improving the city's homeless situation in the future
is listening to the homeless population better.

"That's a lesson that I think we're all learning more and more," she said.
"It's not about us saving people. It's about us working together and coming
together as a community for all our sakes."

EDITOR'S NOTE: This story has been updated to clarify one of Anne Miskey's
statements.

title: Pasadena's 2020 homeless count numbers are in
html:
The number of homeless individuals in Pasadena held relatively steady in 2020, down just 3% from 2019, but the decline may be statistically insignificant, officials say.

Still, when statewide and county homeless counts were seeing double-digit increases in previous years, Pasadena's tally was a "noteworthy success," a city staff report reads, and it's something Union Station Homeless Services Chief Executive Anne Miskey can get behind, even if she's not entirely satisfied.

"We are pleased the results have not gone up," Miskey said in an interview on Monday. "Compared to the numbers we're seeing in the rest of the county, I think it is a testament to the work that's happening in Pasadena."

Figures from the Los Angeles Countywide count, conducted in January by the Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority, are not yet publicly available. The numbers for Pasadena, which conducts its own point-in-time count, typically are announced first.

Miskey celebrated the coordination and support seen between organizations like hers, the city's housing, police and fire departments, and the local faith community.

"There's a level of cooperation that's happening here, compared to other communities," Miskey said. "It's those connections as a community that, I think, have set us apart, and it's something we have to cultivate going forward."

Still, while the results weren't bad, they weren't that great either, she said.

"It's not the numbers we want to see," Miskey said. "We want to see them going down dramatically. … We're on the right track in the community, but this is a time for us to do more and do even better."

The homeless count isn't meant to be a holistic accounting of every single homeless person in the city. It's supposed to be a snapshot of one night in Pasadena - in this case, Jan. 22, 2020.

Compared to 2019, when city volunteers counted 542 people experiencing homelessness, this year they counted 527.

Officials say there's 5% more people living in the city's homeless shelters compared to 2019. Compared to the overall count, there's less wiggle room on these figures, Miskey said, because it's significantly easier for officials to get accurate counts of the population living in shelters.

"Once you're in a shelter, staff are working with you directly to get you into housing," she said, something that Pasadena has done well compared to its neighbors.

Miskey said the city has found homes for "a tremendous amount of people," but more become homeless in Pasadena on a daily basis.

The staff report says that 54% of the people surveyed had been living in Pasadena before they became homeless. On average, they lived in homes or apartments in the city for 21 years before they ended up on the streets.

Compared to 2019, Pasadena saw a 27% increase in homelessness among people ages 62 years or older, the report says. That's despite the fact the demographic only comprises 14% of the city's population.

The trend holds when one looks at older adults, 55 years old and up, which make up 30% of the city's overall population and 40% of the homeless population.

Miskey said this is a trend they've seen around the country, and the seniors who end up homeless are often experiencing it for the first time. They land on the streets when they can't afford the skyrocketing rent increases after their incomes are cut dramatically when, for instance, their spouse dies.

In the African American population, Pasadena's figures held relatively steady compared to 2019 - they're still hugely overrepresented with 31% of the homeless population but only 10% of the city's general population.

"That's true across the country and is a direct result of years of policies that have disproportionately affected black and other communities of color," Miskey said. "Ultimately, blacks were kept out of the housing ownership market, which forced them into rental housing, then we see the dramatic increases in rent in the country and people who have very little equity and forced into low paying jobs.

"All these things come together to make the perfect storm."

Other notable statistics:

* Veterans comprise 7% of the homeless population counted in 2020, which is "relatively stable compared to previous years," the report says.

* The chronically homeless make up slightly more than half of the city's homeless population.

* For the second year in a row, there were no unsheltered homeless families in Pasadena, but 24 families with children were living in the city's shelters. It's a similar proportion that officials saw in 2019.

For Miskey, the key to improving the city's homeless situation in the future is listening to the homeless population better.

"That's a lesson that I think we're all learning more and more," she said. "It's not about us saving people. It's about us working together and coming together as a community for all our sakes."
